results.description:
First get-together! There will be short talks, discussions and open-ended hacking/meeting-nice-people!

We're excited to have two speakers:

• Martinho Fernandes will give an introduction to Rust

•  Alexey Fedorov talks about his new messaging queue in Rust
results.name: Hacking

results.description:
Open Hacking and Learning!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

results.name: Hack and Learn

results.description:
Let's get together and celebrate the first stable Rust release. The days of nightly breaking your builds are (probably) finally over.

There will be talks and drinks! Mozilla has sponsored T-Shirts and Stickers that we will give away during the event.

- Florian Gilcher, who has been doing Rust from (almost) the very beginning, will show how it went from a distributed programming language to the memory-safe high-level systems language that we all love today.

- Our special guest Frank McSherry will talk about (Big) Data Processing in Rust.

After the talks everyone's invited to hang out and talk about the good old days and the future of Rust over a beer, coke or whatever you prefer.
results.name: Rust 1.0 Release Party

results.description:
We're back with our (approximately) third Meetup! So far we have one talk!

We're hosted by the nice people from Blacklane at their awesome office.

Talks

1. Paige Peterson - Rust at MaidSafe

MaidSafe is a company building infrastructure for a peer to peer Internet in Rust with the goal of replacing dependence on servers for storage, communication and eventually computation. Paige Peterson from the MaidSafe team will be presenting an overview of the technology and how developers can get involved using the API to build decentralised applications or contributing to the core libraries through the recently announced bounty system.

2. You? Shoot me (Johann) a message if you want to do a talk!

results.name: Hack and Learn Rust

results.description:
MJ and Max will talk about Leaf and Collenchyma:

We will show that Machine Learning, including the promising subfield of Deep Learning, are based on a few universal as well as intelligible  mathematical concepts - giving an intuitive understanding of how latest Machine Intelligence works. The main part will then introduce the Rust HPC Framework Collenchyma and the Rust Machine Intelligence Framework Leaf. The talk will cover the architecture of these Frameworks and how they relate to other state-of-the-art Frameworks such as Tensorflow(Google) and Caffe(UC Berkley), some interesting low-level implementations in Rust and it's advantages as well as code examples and benchmarks. Leaving the attendants with both a conceptual understanding of Machine Intelligence and the practical insights for building applications in the exciting field of Machine Intelligence.

We are open for lightning talks!
results.name: Machine Learning: Leaf and Collenchyma

results.description:
Rust stable is turning 1.0 and that's a reason to meetup.

We have two great talks lined up:

Maciej Hirsz: Writing a JavaScript compiler with Rust

https://github.com/maciejhirsz

It's not necessary to compile JavaScript, but we do it anyway, and for good reasons. However sometimes in the blitz of productivity it might be good to take a step back, look at our tooling and ask: "is this the best we can do?" So lets take a brief look into the rocket science behind compilers, see why Rust is an excellent choice for the job and how it might help improve the JavaScript ecosystem a bit.

Ryan Levick: Rusty VMs and Emulation

A lot of software, especially older software, is meant to run on specific machines. Whether it's games for a specific platform or some embedded system for a particular piece of hardware, many times we may want to run code on a different machine than it was intended.

In this talk we'll be exploring how to solve this issue by writing an emulator in Rust for a little known "computer" (or rather virtual machine) from the 1970's known as CHIP-8.

Accessibility status of the venue: The venue is wheelchair accessible through an elevator. All doors are wide enough for a wheelchair and there are facilities large enough. Please take note that the toilets are missing handles, though. Please be in touch if you have any further questions.
results.name: Rust 1.0 Anniversary Meetup

results.description:
Talks this time:

Alex Crichton (Rust core team)

An exploration of the Rust project and community since the 1.0 stable release in May 2015 followed by a taste of what's to come from Rust in 2016. We'll take a look at incremental compilation in the compiler, a futures implementation for async I/O, and tooling updates especially around formatting and IDE support.

Florin Lipan (Blacklane) - "Web clients and web mocking for Rust ".

Exploring the current ways to test web clients in Rust and introducing a new crate for HTTP mocking. This will include a short intro on how to write an API client in Rust.

Kamal Marhubi - Rust + nix = easier unix systems programming <3
results.name: June 8th meetup

results.description:
Let's meet up one more time before Rustfest is coming to town!

Talks this time:

- Eduard Bopp will talk about Carboxyl

- Benjamin Kampmann will introduce Your first Web-Service with Rust

Talks descriptions will follow soon.

By attending this event you agree to our Code of Conduct http://berlincodeofconduct.org/
results.name: July Meetup

results.description:
novemb.rs is a Rust code sprint that is happening in a hybrid fashion, both online and offline. It is open to anyone, including beginners interested in learning Rust while building a small project.

The goal is to start new projects, work on your current ones or get involved in new ones. It's a 2 days open hack :).

See http://novemb.rs for details.
results.name: novemb.rs Hack Fest

results.description:
We're back!

We will meet in the brand new Mozilla office for a fresh round of talks, drinks, food and chatter about everyone's favorite programming language.

We have two amazing talks lined up:

An overview of the Servo architecture by Emilio

Emilio is an engineer at Mozilla, working on the experimental Servo browser engine and integrating Stylo (the CSS parts of Servo) into Firefox.

rust ❤️ sensors by Claus
With Rust being a safe and efficient language, it's perfect for embedded and more lower level applications. However, its ecosystem is missing a crucial thing to succeed: Drivers. More often than not reference implementations are in C or Python, and re-implementing them using that code or even the data sheet is often tricky. This talk will explore available drivers, common pitfalls, and show the audience how to implement their own drivers for i2c devices.

A software engineer by trade, Claus runs field engineering at Crate.io, the creators of CrateDB, a distributed SQL database. As a former CTO of a health startup and an Raspberry Pi and Rust (the programming language) enthusiast, Claus also maintains several drivers for sensors in the Rust community. He loves connecting with developers to talk about putting machine data to work in exciting IoT systems.
results.name: Rust Meetup: September 2017

results.description:
Is it time for another Rust meetup?

Absolutely!

We will meet in the beautiful Mozilla office for a fresh round of talks, drinks, food and chatter about everyone's favorite programming language.

As always, we have two amazing speakers lined up for you:

Arvid E. Picciani (https://github.com/aep)

Application container deployment for the Internet of Things with Rust

Solving containerization on very constrained devices will enable a new way we deliver system updates to embedded systems. We’ll learn about one possible approach with korhal’s bolter and how it ties into the interplanetary hash router to deliver content addressable system updates to microcontrollers anywhere, without a cloud.

Arvid is a controversial break-the-whole-box-thinker getting hired to put Linux on stuff where Linux would prefer to not be with deadlines you’d prefer to not have. He’s currently CTO of superscale networks and Founder of korhal.io, an organization dedicated to liberating IoT and preventing consumer lock-in.

Vincent Esche (https://github.com/regexident)

rspec and what it takes to make a BDD test framework in stable Rust

While the existence of native language-level support for unit testing in Rust is a blessing, classical JUnit-style unit testing can feel a bit antiquated at times. You. Just. Keep. Repeating. Yourself. This is where BDD frameworks come in with their shared scopes and user-friendly matchers. Rspec's aim is to provide the BDD testing experience to Rust without the need to bend over backwards or drink the nightly kool-aid. Tests should be just as stable as the rest of your code, if not more. After all who tests your tests if those break?

A mobile dev lead writing Swift at an emerging fitness/health and IoT startup in Berlin by day, and Rustacean by night, Vincent authored cargo modules and rustfmt's comprehensive configuration guide and is currently working on a modern and extensible Support Vector Machine implementation in Rust.

We're looking forward to see you there!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Berlin Rust Meetup

You can follow us on Twitter and watch our recordings of previous Rust meetups.

This event uses a Code of Conduct to make sure everyone feels welcome and safe in our space.

We also host bi-weekly Rust learning groups as part of OpenTechSchool.
results.name: Rust Meetup: October 2017

results.description:
• What we'll do
We invite you to a special edition of our regular Rust Hack and Learn!

The Rust team will be in town and some of them are going to join us for an evening of hacking and learning together in the Berlin Mozilla office.

There will be food, drinks and lightning talks at the end.

If you haven't been to one of our Hack and Learn events yet, here's the description:

Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html . If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (https://github.com/brson/multirust/)(highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

• What to bring
Please bring a laptop! No Rust skills are required...

• Important to know
As always, this event is covered by the Rust Code of Conduct: https://www.rust-lang.org/en-US/conduct.html
results.name: Hack and Learn with the Rust team

meta.description: Access Meetup events using a group, member, or event id. Events in private groups are available only to authenticated members of those groups. To search events by topic or location, see [Open Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/open_events).
